text: it's a living breathing surface and it's
a constant battle to sort of keep them
as healthy and as strong as you possibly
can my name is Neil stubbly and I am the
head groundsmen of the All England Lawn
Tennis Club this will be my twentieth
torment here as as a groundsman I
started here from college so I've
literally started as the tea boy and
worked my way to the top in my industry
you know this is one of the top jobs
that you can have so to take these
courts continue to take them forward you
know and be part of that history with
the rest of the team it's an honor it's
one of those jobs that once you're here
you're here for and for life and it's
just nice to be a part of that so as you
can see it's the surface where we're
down to our playing height now of eight
millimeters this is our playing height
outside of the playing season we bring
that height have cut up to two 13
millimeters for the summer it's 8 to 8
and it's just a process now I've joined
the court out so we are a clay loam base
and what that does is as it dries out it
becomes very firm so that's how we get
our ball bounce so as you can hear a
very hard surface the actual essential
important ingredient is the soil and the
firmness and that's what gives us the
game my normal daily routine during the
champions will be I will wake up at 5
o'clock in the morning I will have a
look at the weather I'll get the early
weather reports will then decide whether
the covers need to come off we then
start cutting marking out all the courts
most courts will play until 9:00 9:15
well then brush the court to make sure
they're nice and clean we'll then look
at the hardness readings and see how
hard they're getting all being well I'm
normally away from here by about 10:30
11:00 every night we've done some
measurements this morning on the soils
just to get the firmness and the courts
are firming up a little bit quicker than
we would like so what we're doing at the
moment is we're just going through the
process of putting a little bit of water
through each court just to make sure
that we keep them near the the magic
number
you're always mindful of what
potentially can go wrong and yeah so you
just constantly worry the whole
championships
sometimes you'll wake up and you've had
a dream where it's day one of the
championships and the baselines have
already worn out before you start it's
not until the morning after the
championships are finished you can
actually relax look back and think yeah
that's a good good successful
Championships if the players don't say
anything then then they're happy it's
not necessarily they have to sort of Pat
us on the back and say great courts team
well done if they don't say anything we
know they're happy and that's good
enough for us
